explanation: This clue was not a dig at @ckstern! You get HIKE (“tramp”) from HI (“hey”) plus KEN with the “back off”—i.e., remove the last letter. #explanationfriday https://t.co/T6J4osc0Uu
VERDI is the “composer” hidden in, or “consumed by,” the phrase “liVER DIsease.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/CwX3bzbnSu
When the phrase TSUNAMI ON is “broken,” or anagrammed, you get MOUNTAINS (“peaks”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/hCIw8W0mnC https://t.co/Mexp7wW4Ga

clue: Oh, look, darling! Beginners just like me (3)
explanation: OLD (“just like me”) is made from the “beginners,” or first letters, of each of the first three words in the clue. #explanationfriday https://t.co/66Ygo6jCe7

clue: Two guys come together in the city I’m visiting right now (7) 🇨🇦
explanation: At the time I wrote this clue, “the city I’m visiting right now” was CALGARY, which splits into two men’s names, CAL and GARY (“two guys come together”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/VhVVLHZbQD

clue: Extreme hotel and places to stay outdoors announced (7)
explanation: INTENSE (“extreme”) is a homophone (“announced”) of INN TENTS (“hotel and places to stay”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/AONmxjbPPx

Happy Canada Day to those who celebrate! And happy #explanationfriday as well: CAST A NET (“go fishing”) gives you CASTANET, a “percussion instrument.” Question mark indicates the not-100%-literal wordplay. https://t.co/FGs87rICh3
KINDLE (“device”) is KIND (“nice”) plus LE (“the French,” or “the” in French). #explanationfriday https://t.co/boJZVW3RWn

clue: In confusion, ask peer for stereo component (7)
explanation: Anagram (“in confusion”) ASK PEER to get SPEAKER, a “stereo component.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/k7bfejIKof

clue: Foodie is inside, testing our metalware (7)
explanation: GOURMET is the “foodie” found “inside” the phrase “testinG OUR METalware.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/ihaCtaNVFe

clue: Part of the head’s sacred space (6)
explanation: In this double definition, the word TEMPLE is both “part of the head” and a “sacred space.” Yes, they have different etymologies! #explanationfriday https://t.co/qAUHcdgCwd

clue: Bird eating bit of nut is ready to use right away (7)
explanation: Tough one! TURNKEY (“ready to use right away,” in a real-estate sense) is TURKEY (“bird”) “eating” the letter N. “Bit of” is a common indicator phrase meaning “take the first letter of the word that follows” (NUT, in this case). #explanationfriday https://t.co/EI7v5Py8zm

clue: South Carolina superhero: The Hyena, say (9)
explanation: SCAVENGER (“the hyena, say”; ignore the deceptive capitalization) is SC (“South Carolina”) plus AVENGER (“superhero”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Q8tOjpqP8D
The typo was LARGER (“bigger”), which is LAGER (“beer,” the word that was meant on the sign in question) “swallowing” the letter R (“right”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Pl6pZVipx6
REGALE (“tell stories”) is RE (“about,” as in the subject line of a memo sense) plus GALE (“storm”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/2l1OOR3NCI
EASTER is the “holiday” you get from anagramming (“messy”) EATERS. #explanationfriday https://t.co/3MfxDgPMQN

clue: Part of the leg is not feeling well, beset by pains (8)
explanation: ACHILLES is the “part of the leg” you get when ILL (“not feeling well”) is “beset by,” or put inside, the word ACHES (“pains”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/KYGUe9a4T9

clue: Take both sides of dudes’ facial hair (6)
explanation: BEAR (“take,” in its “abide” sense) plus “both sides of”—that is, the first and last letters of—DUDES gives you BEARDS (“facial hair”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/KWR50n9vcY

clue: Lady takes possession of California road construction material (7)
explanation: MACADAM is the “road construction material” you get when MADAM (“lady”) “takes possession of” the letters CA (“California”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/wwKN5YGCA0
SHAKIRA is the “Colombian” you get from anagramming (“unusual”) A RAKISH. #explanationfriday https://t.co/CY8vXHhqav

It’s time I explained a few things! RUMMY is both “boozy” and a “card game.” The etymology of the latter appears to be unknown but possibly from the liquor; I decided “unknown” was good enough to call it not an etymological dupe. #explanationfriday https://t.co/yLET87WfWF
PHANTOM is the “spirit” that’s “masked” by, or hidden in, the phrase “elePHANT OMen.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/hjppZZQ074
Reverse (“in retrospect”) the word LAUD (“praise”) to get DUAL (“double”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/ZiLJIRDi54
SADE is the “singer” you get from SAD (“unhappy”) plus E, an abbreviation for “energy.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/p529K28nSg

clue: Bar bill with rounds is verboten (5)
explanation: Add TAB (“bar bill”) to two letter Os (“rounds,” get it?) to get TABOO (“verboten”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/XzDDjusroW
CL is 150 in Roman numerals; add INCH, a “unit,” to get CLINCH, or “secure” (in the verb sense). #explanationfriday https://t.co/vL0gGx7ppg
FLOUR is “a staple,” so “like a staple,” not literally (hence the question mark) is FLOUR-ISH, or FLOURISH (“thrive”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/MRVXFOvaIT
It’s #explanationfriday again! BARRIO is the “neighborhood” you get when BAIO (“actor Scott”) “seizes” RR, the abbreviation for “railroad.” https://t.co/SkMwP07Az0
Easiest of the week: SPAWN, or “generate,” is S (“small”) plus PAWN (“chess piece”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/tQrXmBj4py

clue: Cartoon baby, denied opening, becomes collegian in Texas (5)
explanation: “Deny the opening”—that is, remove the first letter from—MAGGIE, a “cartoon baby,” to get AGGIE, a “collegian in Texas.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/HQLX5V0d23

clue: English philosopher is crooked, bad actor (7)
explanation: Jeremy BENTHAM is the “English philosopher” you get from BENT (“crooked”) plus HAM (“bad actor”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/v2hsCVfwUR
When this clue was posted, “right now” was MEMORIAL DAY, which can be made from the “constituents” (i.e., anagrammed) of MAILED MAYOR. #explanationfriday https://t.co/Nt7nDMu1hg

clue: Country of the Spanish invasion of body of water (6)
explanation: If you “invade” POND, a “body of water,” with LA (“the Spanish,” or “the” in Spanish), you get the “country” of POLAND. #explanationfriday https://t.co/qXBrBCeAOP
A SHE-RIFF is a “phrase about the ladies?” (The question mark indicates that the wordplay isn’t quite literal.) That gets you SHERIFF, an “officer.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/fMF7e9SDWV

clue: NBA star with no time doubled up for band (5,5)
explanation: Take DURANT (“NBA star”), remove the T (“no time”), and “double up” the result to get a “band”—DURAN DURAN. #explanationfriday https://t.co/pvptOEBuzz
FAT (“oil, say”) plus HER (“that lady’s”) gives you FATHER (“dad”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/qfHDNa4J0Y
In this double definition, COW means both “scare” and “farm animal.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/cBBSAyQ3Y5

clue: App in which successful runners make graffiti hit (9)

clue: Drag Race España star “Butt Sex Royalty” embraces part of California (3,7)

Place AUNT, a “relative,” after the letter D (“drive” as in the car gear) to get DAUNT (“demoralize”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/42GOAzKqx1

clue: Between Utah and California, one city (5)
